entries: Hinges, clamps, and telescoping parts make your innovation collapsible and adjustable. It gains the {@trait modular|LOGM} trait for bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing. You can {@action Interact} to collapse the item down to light Bulk or to return it to its normal form. When it's collapsed to light Bulk, it has the concealable trait, which grants you a +2 circumstance bonus to {@skill Stealth} checks and DCs to hide or conceal the weapon.

items.name: Dense Plating
entries: You've encased your armor with incredible plating. While wearing your armor, you gain resistance to slashing damage equal to 2 + half your level.

items.name: Enhanced Resistance
entries: You've improved upon your initial modification's ability to resist damage. The resistance from your initial armor modification increases to 2 + your level. If you have more than one initial modification, choose one to apply this modification to.

items.name: Heavy Construction
entries: You've expanded your innovation into a heavy bulwark while taking none of the drawbacks for doing so. Your innovation becomes heavy armor, and your proficiency in your innovation armor (but no other heavy armor) advances to equal to your proficiency in medium armor. If your Strength score is at least 16, you remove the Speed penalty entirely instead of reducing it to–5 feet. The armor's statistics are: {@b AC Bonus} +5; {@b Dex Cap} +1; {@b Check Penalty} –2 {@b Speed Penalty}–10 feet; {@b Strength} 16; {@b Bulk} 3; {@b Group} {@group composite}; {@b Armor Traits} {@trait bulwark}.

items.name: Layered Mesh
entries: You've woven an incredibly powerful network of interlocking mesh around your armor, catching piercing attacks and diffusing them. While wearing your armor, you gain resistance to piercing damage equal to 2 + half your level.

items.name: Tensile Absorption
entries: You've enhanced the tensile capabilities of your armor, allowing it to bend with bludgeoning attacks. While wearing your armor, you gain resistance to bludgeoning damage equal to 2 + half your level.

items.name: Advanced Weaponry
entries: You've upgraded your construct's weaponry. Choose one of your construct's unarmed attacks to gain your choice of one initial weapon modification, chosen from the list on page 17 or from other initial weapon modifications to which you have access. The unarmed attack must meet any requirements for the chosen traits (such as being a melee attack for entangling form).

items.name: Climbing Limbs
entries: With appendages that can claw or create suction, your construct becomes a capable climber. Your innovation gains a climb Speed equal to half its land Speed.

items.name: Durable Construction
entries: Your innovation is solidly built and can take more punishment before being destroyed. Increase its maximum Hit Points by your level.

items.name: Refined Cortex
entries: Your innovation gains expert proficiency in {@skill Intimidation}, {@skill Stealth}, and {@skill Survival}. For any of these skills in which it was already an expert (because of being an advanced construct companion, for example), it gains master proficiency instead. If you have the revolutionary innovation class feature, these proficiencies improve to master, or legendary if your innovation was already an expert. You must have the upgraded cortex modification to select this modification.

items.name: Inconspicuous Appearance (melee only)
entries: Your innovation is built for easy concealment and surprise attacks. It gains the {@trait backstabber} and {@trait versatile P} traits. If the weapon has light Bulk, it also gains the {@trait concealable|PT:G&G} trait.

items.name: Advanced Rangefinder (ranged only)
entries: A carefully tuned scope or targeting device makes your innovation especially good at hitting weak points. Your innovation gains the {@trait sniper} trait and increases its range increment by 10 feet.

items.name: Aerodynamic Construction (melee only)
entries: You carefully engineer the shape of your weapon to maintain its momentum in attacks against successive targets. Your innovation gains the {@trait sweep} trait and the {@trait versatile S} trait.

items.name: Integrated Gauntlet (one-handed weapon only; can't have the {@trait two-hand} trait)
entries: Combining your weapon with a gauntlet, you make it so that you can quickly switch between attacking with your weapon and tinkering using your hands. Your innovation gains the {@trait free-hand} trait.

items.name: Manifold Alloy
entries: You've devised several alloys containing the best properties of various metals, replacing parts of your weapon or its ammunition with pieces from these alloys. Your weapon innovation is {@item cold iron} and {@item silver}, allowing you to deal more damage to some supernatural creatures, such as demons, devils, and fey.

items.name: Tangle Line ({@trait thrown} only)
entries: Your weapon has an extendable line that can be used to knock your enemies over and allow you to quickly recall the weapon. Your innovation gains the {@trait ranged trip|PT:G&G} trait and the {@trait tethered|PT:G&G} trait.

items.name: Energy Barrier
entries: Your armor's defenses ablate any kind of energy coming your way. While wearing your armor, you gain resistance to all energy damage (acid, cold, electricity, fire, force, negative, positive, and sonic damage) equal to 2 + half your level. You must have the harmonic oscillator, metallic reactance, or thermal insulation modification to select this modification.

items.name: Incredible Resistance
entries: You've improved upon your breakthrough modification's ability to resist damage. Choose one of the following breakthrough modifications your innovation has: dense plating, layered mesh, or tensile absorption. The resistance you gain from that modification increases to 2 + your level.

items.name: Physical Protections
entries: Your armor has so many adjustments and precautions that it can guard against all physical damage. While wearing your armor, you gain resistance to all physical damage (bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage as well as bleed damage) equal to 2 + half your level. You must have the dense plating, layered mesh, or tensile absorption breakthrough modification to select this modification.

items.name: Rune Capacity
entries: Whether you've dabbled in orichalcum or found another engineering solution, you've built your innovation in such a way that it can hold an additional property rune. Your innovation can have one more property rune than a normal item of its kind (to a maximum of four property runes with a {@item +3 armor potency|CRB|+3 potency} armor).

items.name: Flight Chassis
entries: You fit your construct with a means of flight, such as adding rotors or rebuilding it with wings and a lightweight construction. Your innovation gains a fly Speed of 25 feet.

items.name: Runic Keystone
entries: By incorporating a runestone-like device into your innovation, you allow it to hold a property rune even though it isn't a weapon or suit of armor. An armor property rune affects your innovation as if it would affect the wearer of the armor. A weapon property rune grants whatever properties it would normally grant to a weapon to your innovation's unarmed attacks, following all the requirements as normal (for instance, a {@item vorpal|CRB} rune only applies to slashing melee unarmed attacks); if the rune affects only ranged attacks, it has no effect unless your innovation has a built-in ranged attack (from the projectile launcher initial modification, for example). If the rune would affect the physical shape or appearance of the weapon or armor, like {@item glamered|CRB}, the rune has no effect when etched into your construct.

items.name: Resistant Coating
entries: Your innovation is resilient to damage by any means. It gains resistance 5 to all damage (except adamantine).

items.name: Wall Configuration
entries: Your innovation can transform from a mobile construct to a stationary battlefield emplacement. As a 2-action activity that has the {@trait manipulate} trait, your construct unfolds from its usual form into a thin, straight wall of metal and gears up to 10 feet tall and up to 30 feet long. The wall must extend through your innovation's original space. While your construct is a wall, it can't take any actions except to use the same activity to transform back, and it can't defend itself easily, which makes it {@condition flat-footed} and gives it an additional –2 status penalty to its AC. The wall blocks line of sight and effect unless your innovation has half its maximum Hit Points or fewer, at which point holes in the wall allow creatures to see through and attack with standard cover and Tiny creatures to slip past.

items.name: Attack Refiner
entries: Your weapon makes minute recalibrations after every missed attack to ensure the next lands true. Your innovation gains the {@trait backswing} and {@trait shove} traits.

items.name: Deadly Strike
entries: Through precise calculation, you've found the perfect shape for your weapon to deal extreme damage on a well-placed strike. Your innovation gains the {@trait deadly d8} trait. If your innovation already had the {@trait deadly} trait, it increases its deadly die to {@damage d12} instead of gaining {@trait deadly d8}.

items.name: Enhanced Damage
entries: Your innovation is more powerful than other weapons of its kind. Increase your innovation's weapon damage die by one step ({@damage d4} to {@damage d6}, {@damage d6} to {@damage d8}, {@damage d8} to {@damage d10}, {@damage d10} to {@damage d12}). As normal, you can't increase your die by more than one size, so this modification isn't cumulative with complex simplicity.

items.name: Momentum Retainer (melee only)
entries: A special, weighted device lets your weapon retain more of its momentum when you attack. Your innovation gains the {@trait forceful} trait.

items.name: Extensible Weapon (melee only)
entries: Somehow, you've found a way to construct your weapon so that it can extend while leaving its balance unchanged. Your innovation gains the {@trait reach} trait. If the weapon already had the reach trait, it increases your reach by an additional 10 feet, instead of the usual additional 5 feet.

items.name: Impossible Alloy
entries: Other inventors claim it's not even technically possible, but you've managed to create several metal alloys that seem to work for only you, allowing you to damage opponents vulnerable to every one of the seven skymetals. Your innovation is treated as all seven skymetals (abysium, {@item adamantine weapon|CRB|adamantine}, djezet, inubrix, noqual, {@item orichalcum weapon|CRB|orichalcum}, and siccatite). This allows you to deal more damage to a variety of creatures, though you don't apply any of the other special effects for weapons made of those skymetals.

items.name: Rune Capacity
entries: Whether you've dabbled in orichalcum or found another engineering solution, you've built your innovation in such a way that it can hold an additional property rune. Your innovation can have one more property rune than a normal item of its kind (to a maximum of four property runes with a {@item +3 weapon potency|CRB|+3 potency} weapon).

feat.name: Arcane Fists
entries: You value physical perfection as much as mental. The damage die for your fist changes to {@dice 1d6} instead of {@dice 1d4}. Most people take a –2 circumstance penalty when making a lethal attack with nonlethal unarmed attacks because they find it hard to use their fists with deadly force. You don't take this penalty when making a lethal attack with your fist or any other unarmed attacks.
You also gain the critical specialization effects of unarmed attacks in the {@group brawling} group and weapons in the {@group brawling} group.

feat.name: Combat Assessment
entries: You make a telegraphed attack to learn about your foe. Make a melee {@action Strike|CRB}. On a hit, you can immediately attempt a check to {@action Recall Knowledge|CRB} about the target. On a critical hit, you gain a +2 circumstance bonus to the check to {@action Recall Knowledge|CRB}. The target is temporarily immune to Combat Assessment for 1 day.

feat.name: Eschew Materials
entries: You can use clever workarounds to replicate the arcane essence of certain materials. When {@action Cast a Spell|CRB|Casting a Spell} that requires material components, you can provide these material components without a spell component pouch by drawing intricate replacement sigils in the air. Unlike when providing somatic components, you still must have a hand completely free. This ability doesn't remove the need for any materials listed in the spell's cost entry.

feat.name: Familiar
entries: You make a pact with creature that serves you and assists your spellcasting. You gain a familiar (Core Rulebook 217).

feat.name: Raise A Tome
feat.requirements: You're holding a book.
entries: You raise up the book you're holding and flip it open to defend yourself and expedite your studies. The book remains raised until the start of your next turn. While you have a book raised, you gain a +1 circumstance bonus to AC and to {@action Recall Knowledge|CRB} on a subject relevant to the book (such as arcane magic if you're using your spellbook)
If you're a master in the skill you're using to {@action Recall Knowledge|CRB}, the circumstance bonus to the {@action Recall Knowledge|CRB} check is +2 instead.

feat.name: Cantrip Expansion
entries: Dedicated study allows you to prepare a wider range of simple spells. You can prepare two additional cantrips each day.

feat.name: Enhanced Familiar
entries: You infuse your familiar with additional magical energy. You can select four familiar or master abilities each day, instead of two.

feat.name: Spirit Sheath
entries: You've magically constructed an extradimensional sheath for your weapon, typically accessed through a pocket, sleeve, or clothing seam. This sheath is hard to notice, granting a +2 circumstance bonus to your {@skill Stealth} checks to Conceal an Item within it. A spirit sheath can hold only one weapon at a time, and the weapon must be 1 Bulk or less.

You can draw or return a weapon in a spirit sheath as an {@action Interact|CRB} action, as can anyone else holding the object bearing the sheath. When you {@action Cast a Spell|CRB} affected by Striking Spell, you can draw the weapon from your spirit sheath into your hand or hands as part of the {@action Cast a Spell|CRB} activity, storing your spell within the weapon.

feat.name: Bespell Strikes
feat.requirements: Your most recent action was to cast a non‑cantrip spell.
entries: You siphon spell energy into one weapon you're wielding. Until the end of your turn, the weapon deals an extra {@dice 1d6} damage of a type depending on the school of the spell you just cast. You can choose to put the spell energy into your body instead of a weapon, conferring the damage on your unarmed attacks.

items: {@bold Abjuration} force damage
{@bold Conjuration or Transmutation} same type as the weapon
{@bold Divination, Enchantment, or Illusion} mental damage
{@bold Evocation} a type the spell dealt, or force damage if the spell didn't deal damage
{@bold Necromancy} negative damage

feat.name: Spell Parry
feat.requirements: You're wielding only a single one-handed melee weapon and have your other hand or hands free.
entries: You can parry both physical and magical assaults. You gain a +1 circumstance bonus to AC and to saving throws against spells that target you until the start of your next turn as long as you continue to meet the requirements.

feat.name: Steady Spellcasting
entries: Confident in your technique, you don't easily lose your concentration when you {@action Cast a Spell|CRB}. If a reaction would disrupt your spellcasting action, attempt a DC {@flatDC 15} flat check. If you succeed, your action isn't disrupted.

feat.name: Striker's Scroll
entries: You can attach a scroll to your weapon to blend its spell into an attack, carefully folding it around a part of the weapon or pasting it to the weapon's surface. Attaching a scroll requires using the Affix a Talisman action (a 10-minute exploration activity with the manipulate trait found on page 565 of the Core Rulebook). You can have only one scroll affixed to a weapon at a time, and you can't have both a talisman and scroll attached.

You can Cast the Spell from the scroll after using {@action Striking Spell|PT:SoM} to store the scroll's spell in the attached weapon. You can't Cast the Spell in any other way while it's affixed, though you can use Affix a Talisman again to remove the scroll and use it as a normal—if a bit crumpled—scroll.

feat.name: Energize Strikes
feat.requirements: Your most recent action was to {@action Cast a Spell} with the acid, cold, electricity, fire, or sonic trait.
entries: You energize one weapon you're wielding with a spell. For 1 minute, your {@action Strike|CRB|Strikes} with that weapon deal 1 additional damage per weapon damage die. The damage type matches the spell's trait. If the spell had more than one of the eligible traits, you choose the type when you Energize your {@action Strike|CRB|Strikes}.
You can instead put the spell energy into your body, conferring this additional damage on your unarmed attacks.

feat.name: Martial Caster
entries: You've strengthened your spellcasting to power you in combat. You gain two 1st-level spell slots, but you can prepare only certain spells in them: {@spell fleet step|CRB}, {@spell jump|CRB}, {@spell mage armor|CRB}, {@spell magic weapon|CRB}, and {@spell true strike|CRB}. Automatically add these spells to your spellbook.

When you can cast 4th-level magus spells, the extra slots increase to 2nd level and you add the spells {@spell resist energy|CRB}, {@spell spider climb|CRB}, and {@spell water breathing|CRB}. When you can cast 5th-level {@class magus|pt:som} spells, the extra slots increase to 3rd level and you add the spells {@spell feet to fins|CRB} and {@spell haste|CRB}. When you can cast 6th-level {@class magus|pt:som} spells, the extra slots increase to 4th level and you add the spells fly and {@spell freedom of movement|CRB}.

feat.name: Spell Countermeasures
entries: You can protect yourself against magic. You learn the spell countermeasures battle spell (page 11). Increase the number of Focus Points in your focus pool by 1.

feat.name: Capture Spell
feat.trigger: You succeed at your save against a foe's harmful spell targeting you, or a foe fails a spell attack roll against you from a harmful spell.
feat.requirements: You're benefiting from Spell Parry.
entries: When you resist a spell, you capture the magic in your weapon.

You store the spell in the parrying weapon as though you had used {@action Striking Spell|PT:SoM} (losing any spell currently stored in the weapon, as normal). This doesn't change any of the spell's effects based on the result of your saving throw; for instance, you'd still take half damage if you succeeded at a basic save.

feat.name: Standby Spell
entries: One spell is your favored combat technique, and you've practiced it enough that you no longer need to prepare it to cast it. Choose a spell in your spellbook that you could use with {@action Striking Spell|PT:SoM} and that has a level no higher than the highest-level {@class magus|pt:som} spell slot you have. You can Cast this Spell without having it prepared ahead of time by expending a spell slot of a sufficient level to cast the spell.
You can change this spell when you add new spells to your spellbook or by studying your spellbook for 1 hour per level of the newly chosen spell.

feat.name: Runic Impression
entries: You can temporarily replicate the effects of a property rune for your weapon or unarmed attacks. You learn the runic impression battle spell (page 11). Increase the number of Focus Points in your focus pool by 1.

feat.name: Spell Swipe
entries: You attack in an arc and can adapt your stored spell to harm everyone you hit. Make a melee {@action Strike|CRB} and compare the attack roll result to the AC of up to two foes, each of whom must be within your melee reach and adjacent to each other. Roll damage only once and apply it to each creature you hit. A Spell Swipe counts as two attacks for your multiple attack penalty.
If you had a spell stored in the weapon you attacked with (or in your body if you made an unarmed {@action Strike|CRB}), discharging it affects all foes you hit, not just the first target.
If you're using a weapon with the sweep trait, its modifier applies to all your Spell Swipe attacks, including spell attack rolls.

feat.name: Cascading Ray
feat.trigger: You discharge a stored spell that deals acid, cold, electricity, fire, force, negative, positive, or sonic damage.
entries: Magical energy overflows from your Striking Spell, spilling out to extend beyond the creature you struck. This overflowing energy creates a ray targeting a creature within 60 feet of the creature you damaged. Make a spell attack roll against this new target, applying your multiple attack penalty normally. On a hit, the creature takes the same damage the spell deals of one of the triggering types (double damage on a critical hit)

If the spell deals more than one eligible type of damage, you choose one of these types, and the ray deals only the amount of damage from that type. Unlike the spell discharged, your success with the Cascading Ray's spell attack roll isn't improved if your initial {@action Strike|CRB} was a critical hit. This ray has the attack trait, the school and tradition traits of the original spell, and the trait matching the damage type.

feat.name: Comet Spell
feat.trigger: You hit with a ranged {@action Strike} and discharge a stored spell that you had cast from a spell slot.
entries: You create a trail of magical energy that flows from your target back to you. Each creature in a line between you and the target, not including you or the target, takes force damage equal to the spell's level. If the triggering spell was of the evocation school, increase the damage by half the spell's level and change the damage type to one type dealt by the spell (your choice).

feat.name: Healer's Steel
feat.trigger: You gain temporary Hit Points from {@action Cast a Spell|CRB|Casting a Spell} altered by {@action Striking Spell|PT:SoM} using a spell slot.
entries: Rather than just protecting you, the spells you channel into your weapon actually {@spell heal|CRB} you. In addition to the temporary Hit Points you gain from sustaining steel, you can either regain Hit Points equal to twice the spell's level or end any {@condition Persistent Damage|CRB|persistent negative damage} you have. If the spell was of the necromancy school, you can both {@spell heal|CRB} yourself and end {@condition Persistent Damage|CRB|persistent negative damage}.

feat.name: Portal Slide
feat.trigger: You begin {@action Cast a Spell|CRB|Casting a Spell} altered by {@action Striking Spell|PT:SoM} from a spell slot.
entries: You can rapidly make a portal to step through as you store a spell. Rather than {@action Stride|CRB|Striding} or {@action Step|CRB|Stepping} as part of your {@action Cast a Spell|CRB} activity, you teleport up to half your Speed to a clear space you can see (this doesn't trigger reactions). If this would bring another creature with you, the spell is lost. If the spell you cast is of the conjuration or transmutation school, double the maximum distance you can teleport.

feat.name: Quickened Spellstrike
entries: You can muster intense focus to rapidly store a spell. You use Striking Spell. If your next action is to {@action Cast a Spell|CRB} to store in your body or a weapon, reduce the number of actions required to cast the spell by 1 (to a minimum of 1 action).

feat.name: Bespelled Persistence
entries: When you use {@feat Bespell Strikes|PT:G&G|Bespell Strike}, the weapon or unarmed attacks also deal {@dice 1d6} {@condition Persistent Damage|CRB|persistent damage}. This {@condition Persistent Damage|CRB|persistent damage} is of the same type Bespell {@action Strike|CRB|Strikes} deals, except in the case of physical damage, which causes {@condition Persistent Damage|CRB|persistent bleed damage}.

feat.name: Magic Sense
entries: You have a literal sixth sense for ambient magic in your vicinity. You can sense the presence of magic auras as though you were always using a 1st-level {@spell detect magic|CRB} spell. This detects magic in your field of vision only. When you {@action Seek|CRB}, you gain the benefits of a 3rd-level {@spell detect magic|CRB} spell on things you see (in addition to the normal benefits of Seeking). You can turn this sense off and on with a free action at the start or the end of your turn.

feat.name: Overwhelming Spellstrike
entries: You pierce through your foe's resistance. {@action Strike|CRB} a foe. If your {@action Strike|CRB} discharges a stored spell that deals damage, the spell ignores an amount of the target's resistance to acid, cold, electricity, fire, or sonic damage equal to your level. This applies to all damage the spell deals, including {@condition Persistent Damage|CRB|persistent damage} and damage caused by an ongoing effect of the spell, such as the wall created by {@spell wall of fire|CRB}. A creature's immunities are unaffected.

feat.name: School Shroud
feat.requirements: Your most recent action was to cast a non‑cantrip spell.
entries: Your spell has a powerful aftereffect, briefly granting you the effects of a certain spell depending on the school of the spell you cast. This aftereffect lasts until the end of your next turn instead of its usual duration. Using School Shroud again ends any existing spell benefit you gained from School Shroud.

items: {@b Abjuration} {@spell stoneskin|CRB}
{@b Conjuration} {@spell blink|CRB}
{@b Divination} {@spell see invisibility|CRB}
{@b Enchantment} {@spell heroism|CRB}
{@b Evocation} {@spell fire shield|CRB}
{@b Necromancy} {@spell false life|CRB}
{@b Transmutation} {@spell fleet step|CRB}
{@b Illusion} {@spell invisibility|CRB} (ends after a {@condition hostile} action as normal)

feat.name: Hasted Assault
entries: You can speed yourself up to move and attack more swiftly.
You learn the {@spell hasted assault|PT:SoM} battle spell. Increase the number of Focus Points in your focus pool by 1.

feat.name: Preternatural Parry
feat.trigger: You're targeted by a {@action Strike} or a spell attack roll, or you're about to roll a saving throw against a spell effect.
feat.requirements: You're wielding only a single one-handed melee weapon and have your other hand or hands free.
entries: You snap your blade into place to ward off harm at the last second. You gain a +2 circumstance bonus to AC and saving throws against the triggering effect until the start of your next turn.

feat.name: Dispelling Spellstrike
feat.requirements: You have a spell stored in your weapon or body from Striking Spell.
entries: Your stored spell tries to force out the magic affecting a creature you hit. Make a {@action Strike|CRB} against a creature. If this {@action Strike|CRB} discharges the stored spell, you also attempt to counteract a single spell (of your choice) active on the target. The counteract level of Dispelling Spellstrike is equal to the level of the stored spell, and the counteract check modifier is the standard modifier for counteracting with a spell (your Intelligence modifier plus your spellcasting proficiency bonus, plus any bonuses or penalties that specifically apply to counteract checks).

feat.name: Effortless Concentration
feat.trigger: Your turn begins.
entries: You've trained your mind to maintain a spell with hardly a thought. You immediately gain the effects of the {@action Sustain a Spell|CRB} action, allowing you to extend the duration of one of your active {@class magus|pt:som} spells.

feat.name: Second Chance Strike
entries: When your target proves resilient to your magic, you can recall the magic back into your weapon or body to strike again. Whenever you discharge a spell from Striking Spell, if the target takes no effect (from a critical success on their save, a failed spell attack roll, immunity, etc), the spell isn't discharged and you can continue to attempt to discharge it with a later {@action Strike|CRB}. The spell must be discharged before the end of your next turn, as normal for Striking Spell.

feat.name: Versatile Spellstrike
entries: You can channel the entire realm of possibilities of your spellbook into an attack. Once during your daily preparations, you can use a spell slot to hold that infinite potential, rather than using it to prepare a spell. When you use {@action Striking Spell|PT:SoM} to alter a spell, instead of casting a prepared spell, you can expend this spell slot to cast any spell from your spellbook that's at least 2 levels lower than the slot's level. The spell acts in all ways as a spell of 2 levels lower. You don't have any particular spell prepared in that slot until you cast it.

feat.name: Supreme Spellstrike
entries: You've made it almost effortless to cast Striking Spells. You're permanently {@condition quickened}. You can use your extra action only to {@action Strike|CRB} with the unarmed attack or weapon storing a spell from Striking Spell.

feat.name: Whirlwind Spell
entries: You combine the might of a multitarget spell with a whirling flurry of attacks. You use Striking Spell, then {@action Cast a Spell|CRB} with a casting time of 1 or 2 actions, then make a melee {@action Strike|CRB} against each enemy within your reach. Each attack counts toward your multiple attack penalty but doesn't increase your penalty until you've made all your attacks. If you discharge the spell, you can affect each creature you hit with a {@action Strike|CRB}, up to the spell's normal maximum targets.

feat.name: Dual Studies
entries: You and your eidolon have each practiced some skills on your own, though not all your experiences translate with the shared link. Choose two different skills. Your eidolon becomes trained in one of those skills and you become trained in the other skill. At 7th level, you each become an expert in the chosen skills.

feat.name: Sensory Evolution
entries: Your eidolon evolves more acute senses. Your eidolon either gains {@ability low-light vision} and {@ability darkvision}, or gains {@ability scent} as an imprecise sense with a range of 30 feet.
feat.special: You can select this feat twice, choosing the other option the second time.

feat.name: Synthesis
entries: You can manifest your eidolon using your own body as a vessel, taking on their form. When you Manifest your Eidolon in this way, you become your eidolon, rather than them manifesting as a separate creature. While manifested in this way, you use your eidolon's statistics. Your eidolon can act, but you can't except to use Manifest an Eidolon to unmanifest your eidolon. When you do, you remain behind in one square your eidolon occupied when you unmanifested it.

Since you can't act, you can't Cast Spells, activate or benefit from magic items that normally benefit you and not your eidolon, perform actions that have the tandem trait, or use other abilities that require you, and not the eidolon, to act. Your eidolon isn't limited by their distance to you, and you can't be separately targeted. When you reach 0 Hit Points, your eidolon unmanifests from your body, leaving your {@condition unconscious} body behind.

feat.name: Unfetter Eidolon
entries: You've learned magic that lets you temporarily allow your eidolon to travel far from your side. You learn the {@spell unfetter eidolon|PT:SoM} conduit spell. Increase the number of Focus Points in your focus pool by 1.

feat.name: Reinforce Eidolon
entries: You can increase your eidolon's defenses instead of their offense. You gain the {@spell reinforce eidolon|PT:SoM} conduit cantrip.

feat.name: Distracting Summon Spell
entries: You summon a creature exactly in the right spot to distract your foe from your eidolon, providing a perfect opportunity for your eidolon to attack. If the next action you take is to {@action Cast a Spell|CRB} to cast a 3-action summoning spell, when the spell is complete, your eidolon {@action Strike|CRB|Strikes} a foe within reach of both the summoned creature and the eidolon as a free action. The foe is {@condition flat-footed} to the eidolon's {@action Strike|CRB}.

feat.name: Magical Evolution
entries: Your eidolon evolves to cast their own spells. Your eidolon gains the {@action Cast a Spell|CRB} activity and learns two cantrips of their tradition, which they cast as innate spells. Your eidolon uses your spell DC and spell attack modifier for these spells.

feat.name: Alacritous Evolution
entries: Your eidolon evolves to move more quickly on land. Your eidolon gains a +10-foot status bonus to their Speed.

feat.name: Amphibious Evolution
entries: Your eidolon adapts to life both on land and underwater. Your eidolon gains the amphibious trait, allowing them to breathe in water and in air and to avoid the normal –2 penalty for making bludgeoning and slashing unarmed {@action Strike|CRB|Strikes} underwater. They gain a swim Speed equal to their land Speed or 25 feet, whichever is less. Alternatively, if your eidolon is normally aquatic, they gain a land Speed equal to their swim Speed or 25 feet, whichever is less.

feat.name: Tandem Move
entries: You and your eidolon move together with ease. You and your eidolon each use a single action to {@action Stride|CRB}. Either of you that has the corresponding movement type can {@action Burrow|CRB}, {@action Climb|CRB}, {@action Fly|CRB}, or {@action Swim|CRB} instead of Striding.

feat.name: Unarmed Evolution
entries: Your eidolon's unarmed attack evolves and gains a special trait. Choose one of your eidolon's starting melee unarmed attacks. The attack gains one of the following traits, which you choose when you gain this feat: disarm, nonlethal, shove, trip, or versatile. If you choose versatile, also choose whether it's B, P, or S.

feat.name: Climbing Evolution
entries: Your eidolon can climb with ease. Your eidolon gains a climb Speed equal to half their Speed or 25 feet, whichever is less.

feat.name: Hulking Evolution
entries: Your eidolon evolves, growing substantially in size. Your eidolon becomes Large, instead of their previous size. This doesn't change any other statistics for your eidolon.
Because of the special link you share, you can ride your eidolon without getting in each other's way (see the Riding Independent Creatures sidebar).

feat.name: Ostentatious Arrival
entries: When you summon creatures or manifest your eidolon, there always seems to be an explosion. If the next action you take is to Manifest your Eidolon or to {@action Cast a Spell|CRB} to cast a 3-action summoning spell, the summoned eidolon or creature appears in an explosion of energy or other visually impressive display.

This deals {@damage 1d4} fire damage per spell level (or {@damage 1d4} damage per 2 levels you have when Manifesting your Eidolon) to all creatures except you within a 10-foot emanation around the eidolon or summoned creature.
If the eidolon or summoned creature has the acid, cold, electricity, sonic, or water trait, the damage is that type instead (or cold damage in the case of the water trait).

feat.name: Summoner Shield Evolution
entries: Your eidolon uses their manifested form to protect you when you're nearby. After your eidolon uses this action, you gain a +2 circumstance bonus to AC until the beginning of your next turn. This bonus applies only as long as you're in your eidolon's reach (in most cases, this means your eidolon is adjacent to you or in your space). This has no effect if you're not separately present, such as when using Synthesis.

feat.name: Flickering Evolution
entries: Your eidolon has gained the ability to make their ectoplasmic form briefly less substantial to avoid attacks while scouting ahead. Your eidolon can switch from their normal form to a less substantial flickering form or quasi-tangible ectoplasm. While in their flickering form, they gain resistance to all damage (except force and negative) equal to half your level. However, they can't use any of their {@action Strike|CRB|Strikes} or actions requiring a fully physical form like {@action Grapple|CRB}, {@action Shove|CRB}, or {@action Trip|CRB}. Snapping back to their normal form is easier than diffusing themself into a flickering form. Your eidolon can switch back to their normal form as a single action, which also has the concentrate trait.

feat.name: Greater Magical Evolution
entries: Your eidolon further evolves to gain more powerful magic.

Choose one 2nd-level spell and one 1st-level spell of your eidolon's tradition. Your eidolon can cast them each once per day as innate spells. At every even level after you take this RIDING INDEPENDENT CREATURES If a creature tries to ride your eidolon, both you and the riding creature each regain only 2 actions at the start of your turns each round, as both the eidolon and the riding creature interfere with one another's actions. If you have the Hulking Evolution feat, you're able to ride on your eidolon without this drawback.
feat, your eidolon can swap one of these innate spells for a new innate spell 2 or more levels lower than your highest-level spell slot.

feat.name: Ranged Evolution
entries: Your eidolon has developed a ranged attack. Your eidolon gains a ranged unarmed attack with a range increment of 30 feet that deals {@damage 1d6} damage and has the magical trait. When you select this feat, choose a damage type from acid, bludgeoning, cold, electricity, fire, negative, piercing, positive, or slashing. If your eidolon is a celestial, fiend, or monitor with an alignment other than true neutral, you can instead choose a damage type in their alignment (for example, you could choose good or lawful if your lawful good angel eidolon gained this attack).

feat.name: Boost Summons
entries: Your ability to augment your eidolon extends to also benefit creatures you summon. When you cast boost eidolon, in addition to targeting your eidolon, it also targets any of your summoned creatures within 60 feet, granting them the same effects.

feat.name: Protective Bond
feat.trigger: You and your eidolon are both in the area of a damaging effect.
entries: You call upon the power of your bond to protect you both from harm. If you and your eidolon would take different amounts of damage from the area effect, you take the lower amount of damage instead of the greater amount of damage.

feat.name: Transpose
entries: With a flash, you switch places with your eidolon. You and your eidolon each teleport to the other's position.

feat.name: Conduit Focus
entries: Your focus recovers faster. If you've spent at least 2 Focus Points since the last time you Refocused, you recover 2 Focus Points when you {@action Refocus|CRB} instead of 1.

feat.name: Summoner's Call
feat.trigger: You or your eidolon takes damage.
feat.requirements: Your eidolon is manifested and more than 5 feet away from you.
entries: In a moment of danger, you draw upon your link to quickly call your eidolon to your side. Your eidolon teleports from their previous location to an open space adjacent to you.

feat.name: Transmogrify
entries: You've learned how to transmogrify your eidolon in various ways to suit the circumstances of the day. Each day during your daily preparations, choose one evolution feat of 6th level or lower. Your eidolon gains that feat until your next daily preparations.

feat.name: Resilient Evolution
entries: Your eidolon grows a tougher hide, manifests armor, or otherwise becomes particularly resilient against physical attacks. They gain resistance to physical damage equal to their Constitution modifier.

feat.name: Spellguard Evolution
entries: Your eidolon evolves to protect themself from spells. They gain a +1 status bonus to all saving throws against magic.

feat.name: Towering Evolution
entries: Your eidolon further evolves, becoming more enormous and gaining a greater reach over the battlefield. Your eidolon becomes Huge, instead of Large, and the reach on all their attacks increases to 10 feet.

feat.name: Effortless Concentration
feat.trigger: Your turn begins.
entries: You maintain a spell with hardly a thought. You immediately gain the effects of the {@action Sustain a Spell|CRB} action, allowing you to extend the duration of one of your active spells.

feat.name: Winged Evolution
entries: Your eidolon grows wings, allowing them to fly. Your eidolon gains a fly Speed equal to their Speed.

feat.name: Conduit Wellspring
entries: The power between you and your eidolon replenishes your focus. If you've spent at least 3 Focus Points since the last time you Refocused, you recover 3 Focus Points when you {@action Refocus|CRB} instead of 1.

feat.name: True Transmogrification
entries: You can make incredibly expansive adjustments to your eidolon to prepare for virtually any situation you might find yourself in. Each day during your daily preparations, when you apply your evolution feat from Transmogrify, you can also swap out any number of other evolution feats you have, each for a different evolution feat of the same level or lower. These swaps last until your next daily preparations.

feat.name: Twin Eidolon
entries: You can transform yourself to match your eidolon. When you Manifest your Eidolon, in addition to their normal manifestation, you can call upon their powers to transform yourself into an exact duplicate of your eidolon until the eidolon becomes unmanifested. You can't use this if you Manifest your Eidolon in an unusual way, such as with the Synthesis feat. While a duplicate of your eidolon, you use your eidolon's statistics other than your mental ability modifiers, including their evolutions. You can't cast spells (unless they're spells your eidolon could cast), activate or benefit from magic items that normally benefit you and not your eidolon, or use other actions your eidolon can't normally perform. Any spells you cast with a limited number of uses count against your eidolon's uses. You can Manifest your Eidolon again to end this effect and return to your normal form.

feat.name: Eidolon's Avatar
feat.prerequisites: eidolon from a plane other than the Material Plane
entries: Your complete connection to your eidolon and your eidolon's growth alongside you into a being of great power grant you special privileges within another plane. Once per day, you can cast {@spell plane shift|CRB} as an innate spell of your eidolon's tradition, but only to travel to the plane of origin of your eidolon. When you cast it this way, its casting time is 1 minute, your link to your eidolon is a sufficient tuning fork for this spell, and you appear exactly where you want to be. If you're on your eidolon's home plane due to this spell, you can return to the point you left when you cast it by spending a single action, which has the concentrate trait and the trait matching your eidolon's tradition.

If you conduct the commune ritual to contact entities from your eidolon's plane that are {@condition friendly} to your eidolon, you don't have to pay any cost and you automatically get a critical success.

feat.name: Eternal Boost
entries: Your link with your eidolon is so intense that you can always boost your eidolon. You're permanently {@condition quickened}; you can use your extra action only to cast boost eidolon or reinforce eidolon. While in exploration mode, you can declare that you're also continually casting boost eidolon or reinforce eidolon even while using a different exploration activity. If you do, even before your first turn in a combat encounter, that cantrip is active as if you had cast it on your previous turn.

feat.name: Cover Fire
feat.requirements: You're wielding a loaded firearm or crossbow, and a foe you can see within the weapon's maximum range has cover.
entries: You lay down suppressive fire to protect your allies and pin down your opponents. You make a firearm or crossbow {@action Strike|CRB} targeting the foe, who must decide whether to duck behind cover (no action required) or not before you roll your attack roll. If the target ducks, it Takes Cover against your attack, gaining a +4 circumstance bonus to AC from greater cover, but also takes a –2 circumstance penalty to ranged attacks until the end of its next turn. This greater cover applies only against your {@action Strike|CRB}, not to future attacks. If the target chooses not to duck, the {@action Strike|CRB} functions normally.

feat.name: Firearm Ace
entries: You have a practiced understanding of firearms' workings, their mechanisms, and the best way to utilize them. When you're wielding a firearm and {@action Interact|CRB} to reload it, you gain a +2 circumstance bonus to the damage roll on your next {@action Strike|CRB} with that firearm. If the firearm is a simple firearm, increase the damage die size for that attack by one step. You must make the attack before the end of your turn or these benefits are lost.

feat.name: Hit The Dirt!
feat.trigger: A creature you can see attempts a ranged {@action Strike} against you.
entries: You fling yourself out of {@spell harm|CRB}'s way, perhaps through quick thinking or pure instinct. You {@action Leap|CRB} to avoid {@spell harm|CRB}, gaining a +2 circumstance bonus to AC against the triggering attack.
Regardless of whether or not the triggering attack hits, you land {@condition prone} after completing your {@action Leap|CRB}.

feat.name: Sword And Pistol
entries: You're experienced in combining melee attacks with shots from a firearm or crossbow, quickly adapting your range and style to the current situation. When you make a successful ranged {@action Strike|CRB} against an opponent within your melee reach using a firearm or crossbow, that opponent becomes {@condition flat-footed} against your next melee attack. When you successfully {@action Strike|CRB} an opponent with a melee weapon, the next ranged {@action Strike|CRB} you make against that opponent doesn't trigger reactions that would trigger only on a ranged attack but not a melee attack, such as {@action Attack of Opportunity|CRB}.
The benefit on your next {@action Strike|CRB} from either use of Sword and Pistol is lost if not used by the end of your next turn.

feat.name: Assisting Shot
entries: With a quick shot, you interfere with a foe during combat.

Make a {@action Strike|CRB} with a firearm or crossbow. If the {@action Strike|CRB} hits, the next creature other than you to attack the same target before the start of your next turn gains a +1 circumstance bonus to their roll, or a +2 circumstance bonus if your {@action Strike|CRB} was a critical hit.

feat.name: Blast Lock
feat.requirements: You're wielding a loaded firearm.
entries: Sometimes taking the shortest distance between two points involves removing an obstacle or two. You shoot the required firearm at a lock within 10 feet. Make your attack roll against the DC required to {@action Pick a Lock|CRB|Pick the Lock}.

entries.Critical Success: You open the lock, or you achieve two successes toward opening a complex lock.
entries.Success: You open the lock, or you achieve one success toward opening a complex lock.
entries.Failure: You fail to open the lock, and your shot makes it harder to open. Future attempts to {@action Pick a Lock|CRB|Pick the Lock} take a –2 circumstance penalty.
entries.Critical Failure: You fail to open the lock, and your shot makes it much harder to open. Future attempts to {@action Pick a Lock|CRB|Pick the Lock} take a–4 circumstance penalty.

feat.name: Pistol Twirl
feat.requirements: You're wielding a loaded, one-handed ranged weapon.
entries: Your quick gestures and performative flair distract an opponent, leaving them vulnerable to your attack. You {@action Feint|CRB} against an opponent within the required weapon's first range increment, rather than an opponent within melee reach. On a success or critical success, the foe is {@condition flat-footed} against your melee and ranged attacks, rather than only your melee attacks. On a critical failure, you're {@condition flat-footed} against both the target's melee and ranged attacks, rather than only its melee attacks.

feat.name: Quick Draw
entries: You draw your weapon and attack with the same motion. You {@action Interact|CRB} to draw a weapon, then {@action Strike|CRB} with that weapon.

feat.name: Risky Reload
feat.requirements: You're wielding a firearm.
entries: You've practiced a technique for rapidly reloading your firearm, but it's a dangerous gamble with your firearm's functionality.
{@action Interact|CRB} to reload a firearm, then make a {@action Strike|CRB} with that firearm. If the {@action Strike|CRB} fails, the firearm misfires.

feat.name: Warning Shot
feat.requirements: You're wielding a loaded firearm.
entries: Who needs words when the roar of a gun is so much more succinct? You attempt to {@action Demoralize|CRB} a foe by firing your weapon into the air, using the firearm's maximum range rather than the usual range of 30 feet. This check doesn't take the–4 circumstance penalty if the target doesn't share a language with you.

feat.name: Alchemical Shot
feat.requirements: You have an alchemical bomb worn or in one hand, and are wielding a loaded firearm.
entries: You've practiced a technique for mixing alchemical bombs with your loaded shot. You {@action Interact|CRB} to retrieve the bomb (if it's not already in your hand) and pour it onto your ammunition, consuming the bomb. Then {@action Strike|CRB} with your weapon. The {@action Strike|CRB} deals damage of the same type as the bomb (for instance, fire damage for {@class alchemist|CRB}'s fire), and it deals an additional {@dice 1d6} {@condition Persistent Damage|CRB|persistent damage} of the same type as the bomb. If the {@action Strike|CRB} fails, you take {@dice 1d6} damage of the same type as the bomb you used, and the firearm misfires.
The {@condition Persistent Damage|CRB|persistent damage} increases to {@dice 2d6} if the bomb is level 11 or higher, or {@dice 3d6} if it's level 17 or higher.

feat.name: Black Powder Boost
feat.trigger: You Leap.
feat.requirements: You're wielding a loaded firearm.
entries: While dashing into position, you fire your weapon behind you to speed yourself along. You fire your weapon beneath or behind you, adding 10 feet to either the horizontal or vertical distance you travel. If your {@action Leap|CRB} required a roll (such as a {@action High Jump|CRB} or {@action Long Jump|CRB}), you can use this reaction after determining the result.

feat.name: Running Reload
entries: You can reload your weapon on the move. You {@action Stride|CRB}, {@action Step|CRB}, or {@action Sneak|CRB}, then {@action Interact|CRB} to reload.

feat.name: Cauterize
feat.requirements: You're wielding a firearm that you've fired this turn, and you or an adjacent ally are taking persistent bleed damage.
entries: You press your gun's heated barrel to your wounds or those of an ally, instantly granting a flat check to end the bleed with a lower DC for particularly effective assistance (Pathfinder Core Rulebook 621)

feat.name: Pistolero's Challenge
entries: With a stern callout, a carefully chosen barb, or some other challenging declaration, you demand your foe's attention in a duel. Choose an opponent within 30 feet who you can perceive and can hear you, and make your choice of a {@skill Deception} or {@skill Intimidation} check. No matter the result of the check, the foe is temporarily immune to your Pistolero's Challenge until noon the next day. You can have only one challenge in effect at a time; challenging a new opponent ends this effect on any current target. Otherwise, the effect lasts until one of you is defeated or flees or the encounter ends.

entries.Success: Both you and the opponent gain a +2 status bonus to damage rolls with {@action Strike|CRB|Strikes} made against each other. If you're a master in the skill you used for the check, the status bonus to damage rolls increases to +3, and if you're legendary, it increases to +4.
entries.Critical Failure: You become {@condition frightened} 1 and can't use this ability again for 1 minute.

feat.name: Reloading Strike
feat.requirements: You're wielding a firearm or crossbow and your other hand either wields a one-handed melee weapon or is empty.
entries: You attack and then reload your gun in one fluid movement.
{@action Strike|CRB} an opponent within reach with your melee weapon or an unarmed attack, and then {@action Interact|CRB} to reload. You don't need a free hand to reload in this way.

feat.name: Scatter Blast
feat.requirements: You're wielding a loaded firearm that has the scatter trait.
entries: You pack your weapon with additional shot and powder, creating a risky but devastating arc of destruction. Make a ranged {@action Strike|CRB} with the required weapon. The range of your weapon increases from 15 feet to 30 feet, or 30 feet to 60 feet.
If the weapon's range is already 60 feet or greater, this ability has no effect. The {@action Strike|CRB} gains the following failure conditions.

entries.Critical Failure: The firearm explodes, becoming {@condition broken}, and deals its normal weapon damage (including fundamental and property runes) to all creatures in a 20-foot burst with a basic Reflex save against your class DC.

feat.name: Shattering Shot
feat.requirements: You're wielding a loaded firearm or crossbow and have a worn or wielded bomb that has the splash trait.
entries: You fling a bomb into the air and then shoot it, causing a damaging rain over a wide area. If necessary, you {@action Interact|CRB} to draw the bomb and re-grip your weapon. You throw your bomb to the corner of a square within your firearm's first range increment and shoot it with your firearm. All creatures in a 15-foot burst of the bomb take splash damage equal to the amount of precision damage One Shot, One Kill deals. The damage type is the same as the bomb would deal.

feat.name: Grit And Tenacity
feat.trigger: You fail a Fortitude or Will save.
entries: You call upon deep reserves of toughness and mental fortitude to power through an otherwise debilitating effect. Reroll the triggering save with a +2 circumstance bonus.

feat.name: Paired Shots
feat.requirements: You're wielding two loaded one-handed crossbows or firearms.
entries: Your shots strike their target almost simultaneously. Make two {@action Strike|CRB|Strikes}, one with each of your two ranged weapons and each using your current multiple attack penalty. Both {@action Strike|CRB|Strikes} must have the same target.
If both attacks hit, combine their damage and then add any applicable effects from both weapons. You add any precision damage only once to the attack of your choice.
Combine the damage from both {@action Strike|CRB|Strikes} and apply resistances and weaknesses only once. This counts as two attacks when calculating your multiple attack penalty.

feat.name: Return Fire
entries: You're quick enough to line up a shot even while diving to the ground. When you use your Hit the Dirt! reaction, at any point during your {@action Leap|CRB}, you can also make a ranged {@action Strike|CRB} with a loaded firearm or crossbow against the creature whose attack triggered the reaction.

feat.name: Shooter's Aim
entries: You take an extra moment to carefully align your aim and breathing. Make a ranged weapon {@action Strike|CRB}. You gain a +2 circumstance bonus to this {@action Strike|CRB}'s attack roll and ignore the target's concealment. If you're using a firearm with the {@trait unsteady|PT:G&G} trait, you don't take the normal circumstance penalty for firing without using a {@item tripod|PT:G&G} or {@action Interact|CRB} action to aim on this {@action Strike|CRB}.

feat.name: Smoke Curtain
feat.requirements: You're wielding a loaded firearm.
entries: You load an extra dose of black powder into your shot, causing it to belch out a roiling cloud of smoke. Make a {@action Strike|CRB} with your firearm to create a cloud of smoke in a 20-foot burst centered on your location. Creatures are {@condition concealed} while within the smoke, and creatures outside the area are {@condition concealed} to creatures within the smoke. The smoke dissipates in 1 round. The {@action Strike|CRB} gains the following critical failure effect.

entries.Critical Failure: The firearm misfires (see sidebar on page 4).

feat.name: Called Shot
entries: You target a specific part of your foe's body, damaging the chosen limb or body part in a way that hinders your foe's ability to move, fight, or think. Declare a portion of your foe's anatomy to target and make a ranged weapon {@action Strike|CRB}. If you hit and deal damage, apply one of the following effects to the target until the end of your next turn, based on the body part you targeted.

items: {@bold Arms} (or another limb used for attacks, such as a tentacle) The target is {@condition enfeebled} 2. On a critical hit, it's also {@condition enfeebled} 1 for 1 minute.
{@bold Head} The target is {@condition stupefied} 2. On a critical hit, it's also {@condition stupefied} 1 for 1 minute.
{@bold Legs} (or tail on a legless creature) The target takes a–10-foot status penalty to its Speeds. On a critical hit, it also takes–5-foot penalty to its Speeds for 1 minute.

{@bold Wings} If the target is flying using its wings, it immediately falls 20 feet, or 40 feet on a critical hit. The fall is gradual enough that if it causes the target to hit the ground, the target takes no damage from the fall.

feat.name: Deflecting Shot
feat.trigger: An ally within the first range increment of your firearm or crossbow is hit by an attack, and you can see the attacker.
feat.requirements: You're wielding a loaded firearm or crossbow.
entries: When your weapon is loaded, you're always ready to fire it to deflect an attack against your ally. The ally gains a +2 circumstance bonus to their AC against the triggering attack.

You use this reaction after the result of the attack roll is revealed, so you know whether the +2 will make a sufficient difference (for example, whether it will turn a success into a failure or a critical success into a success).

feat.name: Redirecting Shot
feat.trigger: An ally misses with a ranged attack that uses a {@trait thrown} weapon or ammunition.
feat.requirements: You're wielding a loaded firearm or crossbow.
entries: Seeing your ally's attack about to go astray, you fire your weapon to right its course. Make an attack roll with your firearm or crossbow against the target of the triggering attack, ignoring any bonus the target would gain against you from lesser or standard cover. Your ally's attack uses your attack roll instead of their attack roll.

feat.name: Trick Shot
feat.requirements: You're wielding a loaded firearm.
entries: You shoot not at your foe, but at an object nearby. Make a {@action Strike|CRB} with your firearm against an AC of 25, or a different AC at the GM's discretion. Instead of hitting your foe, your attack hits an object behind or to the side of your target, creating one of the following effects. The GM might determine a particular effect isn't a valid option, such as using explosive barrel when there's no such object on the battlefield. The GM determines such cases and should inform you before you spend the actions for a Trick Shot.

items: {@bold Dislodge Object} Your attack knocks an unattended object of no more than 2 Bulk out of position, moving it up to 10 feet in a direction of your choice. For example, the weapon could knock a {@class wizard|CRB}'s crystal ball off a table.

{@bold Explosive Barrel} Your attack strikes a barrel of expensive rum, a vial of volatile alchemical fluids, an erupting demonic pustule, or some other explosive object. The object explodes in a 20-foot burst and all creatures in the area take {@dice 6d6} damage with a basic Reflex save against your class DC. The damage type is chosen by the GM based on the exploding object. Increase the damage by {@dice 1d6} for every 2 levels you have above 10th

feat.name: Glancing Shot
entries: Even when your shots don't land cleanly, they still land close enough to inflict some damage. Make a ranged {@action Strike|CRB}. It gains the following failure effect.

entries.Failure: Your attack deals any damage it would have dealt on a hit, excluding all damage dice (this removes damage dice from weapons, runes, spells, and special abilities, in addition to weapon damage dice).

feat.name: Incredible Ricochet
entries: After your first shot singles out your opponent's position, you direct another shot that ricochets around obstacles and strikes unerringly. Make a ranged weapon {@action Strike|CRB} against a creature you previously attacked this turn. You ignore the target's {@condition concealed} condition and all cover.

feat.name: Penetrating Fire
feat.requirements: You're wielding a loaded firearm or crossbow.
entries: You blast a bullet through one foe and into another. Choose two targets, one of which would give the other lesser cover against your ranged attacks. Make a single ranged {@action Strike|CRB} with the required weapon against both targets. This attack ignores any lesser cover the nearer target provides the other.
Roll damage only once, and apply it to each creature you hit. Penetrating Fire counts as two attacks for your multiple attack penalty.

feat.name: Shooter's Camouflage
entries: You specialize in blending into a particular type of environment, allowing you to disappear from sight after taking your shot. Choose either natural or urban terrain. In the chosen terrain, you can {@action Hide|CRB} and {@action Sneak|CRB} even without cover or being {@condition concealed}.

feat.name: True Grit
entries: Hardened by conflict, you possess an intractable stubbornness.
If the reroll granted by your Grit and Tenacity reaction is a success, you get a critical success instead; if it's a critical failure, you get a failure instead.

feat.name: Dance Of Thunder
feat.requirements: You're wielding a loaded firearm or crossbow and not fatigued.
entries: Your steps echo with the thunderous retort of exploding black powder as you dance a dance of death. Use any of the following actions you choose in any order: {@action Step|CRB}, {@action Strike|CRB} against a target within your firearm's first range increment, and {@action Interact|CRB} to reload. If you attempted a {@action Strike|CRB} and it succeeds, you can repeat these three actions again in any order. If you attempted a {@action Strike|CRB} in the second set and succeed, you can repeat the actions one last time. After using Dance of Thunder, you become {@condition fatigued} for 1 minute.

feat.name: Showstopper
entries: Your twirling weapons create a distracting dance that your enemies find difficult to look away from. When using Pistol Twirl to {@action Feint|CRB}, you can target all enemies within your weapon's first range increment who you can perceive and who can see you. You roll one {@skill Deception} check and compare it against each target's {@skill Perception} DC.

feat.name: Two-weapon Flurry
feat.requirements: You're wielding two weapons, each in a different hand.
entries: You attack with both your weapons in a furious barrage. {@action Strike|CRB} twice, once with each weapon.

feat.name: Fatal Bullet
entries: You're especially talented at striking your enemies' most vulnerable areas. When you critically hit with a firearm that has the fatal trait, you deal an additional die of the appropriate size and damage type for that trait after doubling the weapon's damage. For example, after a critical hit with a fatal d12 weapon, you add an additional {@dice 1d12} damage to the attack after doubling its damage.

feat.name: Hair Trigger
entries: Prerequisite initial deed that allows you to {@action Interact|CRB} to draw a weapon Whether a duel to the death or getting the {@spell jump|CRB} on your foe, no one can react faster than you can pull your trigger.

When using your initial deed, instead of Interacting to draw a weapon, you can {@action Strike|CRB} with a firearm or crossbow you're already wielding. If this {@action Strike|CRB} hits, the target is also {@condition flat-footed} until the end of your first turn of the encounter.
feat.special: If your initial deed allows you to {@action Interact} to draw a weapon more than once, this feat allows you to replace one of these {@action Interact} actions and use the other one to draw a weapon. You can't replace both {@action Interact} actions with {@action Strike|CRB|Strikes}, but you can draw a loaded firearm or crossbow and immediately shoot it.

feat.name: Instant Return
feat.trigger: An enemy misses you with a ranged attack using a type of ammunition appropriate to your weapon (for instance, a bullet if you're wielding a firearm).
feat.requirements: You're wielding an unloaded firearm or crossbow.
entries: With a single fluid gesture, you catch a projectile out of the air, load it in your weapon, and fire it back at the attacker.

{@action Interact|CRB} to load the projectile into your weapon and then make a {@action Strike|CRB} with the required weapon against the triggering opponent. Since you're using the foe's ammunition, this {@action Strike|CRB} applies any special effects that ammunition would have (for instance, if it was explosive ammunition, it would explode in a burst of fire)

feat.name: Piercing Critical
entries: Your attacks with your preferred weapons deal especially devastating wounds. When you {@action Strike|CRB} with a firearm or crossbow for which you have legendary proficiency, you critically succeed if you roll a 19 on the die as long as that result is a success. This has no effect on a 19 if the result would be a failure.

feat.name: Unerring Shot
entries: Your senses are finely tuned to the slightest variations in the air, allowing you to place your shot exactly where you intend from any range. When attacking with a ranged weapon in which you have master or greater proficiency, ignore the penalty from its range increment (its maximum range is unchanged). Additionally, if your target has cover against your attack with such a weapon, it doesn't gain the bonus to AC if it has lesser cover, gets only the benefits of lesser cover if it has standard cover, or gains only the benefits of standard cover if it has greater cover.

feat.name: Perfect Readiness
entries: You prepare to fire with an instinctive speed that surpasses thought. You're permanently {@condition quickened}. You can use your extra action only to {@action Step|CRB} or {@action Interact|CRB} to reload.

feat.name: Slinger's Reflexes
entries: Your have a preternaturally sharp ability to react to unexpected circumstances. At the start of each enemy's turn, you gain an additional reaction you can use on only that turn to take a gunslinger reaction.

feat.name: Built-in Tools
entries: You've built tools into your innovation, allowing you to use them easily. When you take this feat, choose a set of tools you own of 1 Bulk or less, which become part of your innovation without increasing its Bulk. As long as you are wielding, wearing, or adjacent to your innovation, you have the same quick access to these tools as the tools you're wearing, and they don't count against the usual limit of tools you can wear.

feat.name: Explosive Leap
entries: You aim an explosion downward and directly beneath your feet in order to launch yourself into the air. You {@spell jump|CRB} 30 feet in any direction without touching the ground. You must land on a space of solid ground within 30 feet of you, or else you fall after using your next action.
feat.special: If your innovation is a minion, it can take this action rather than you.

feat.name: Prototype Companion
entries: You've created a construct companion, and while it might not be an innovation, it serves as a trustworthy minion. You gain a prototype construct companion (page 26).

feat.name: Tamper
entries: You tamper with a foe's weapon or armor. Choose either a weapon held by an enemy in your reach or a suit of armor worn by an enemy in your reach. Attempt a {@skill Crafting} check against the enemy's Reflex DC.

entries.Critical Success: Your tampering is incredibly effective. If you tampered with a weapon, the enemy takes a –2 circumstance penalty to attack rolls and damage rolls with that weapon. If you tampered with armor, the armor hampers the enemy's movement, causing them to be flatfooted and take a–10-foot penalty to their Speeds. Either effect lasts until the enemy Interacts to remove the effect.
entries.Success: Your tampering is temporarily effective. As critical success, but the effect ends after 1 round even if the enemy hasn't Interacted to end it.
entries.Critical Failure: Your tampering backfires dramatically, causing a small explosion from your own tools or gear. You take fire damage equal to your level.

feat.name: Unstable Repair
entries: You quickly fix your innovation, at the cost of its stability. You {@action Repair|CRB} your innovation. {@action Repair|CRB} has the unstable trait when used this way. You don't have to place the innovation on a flat surface, but you do need to be adjacent to it (including holding or wearing it) as well as have a repair kit as normal.

feat.name: Kickback Strike
entries: You activate devices on your innovation, causing your weapon to strike with extreme recoil that helps you disengage. {@action Strike|CRB} a foe and then {@action Stride|CRB} twice. You must end each {@action Strike|CRB} further from the foe than you began.

feat.name: No! No! I Created You!
feat.trigger: Your construct companion would become confused or controlled.
entries: You appeal to your construct companion's bond with its creator to have it break free of a controlling effect. Attempt to counteract the effect that {@condition confused} or {@condition controlled} your construct companion using your {@skill Crafting} modifier for the counteract check and half your level rounded up for the counteract level.

feat.name: Searing Restoration
entries: They told you there was no way that explosions could {@spell heal|CRB} people, but they were fools—fools who didn't understand your brilliance! You create a minor explosion using your innovation that cauterizes wounds and vaporizes medicinal herbs, restoring {@dice 1d4} Hit Points for each level you have to you or an adjacent living creature.
feat.special: If your innovation is a minion, it can take this action rather than you. Because it's not a living creature, it can't use the ability on itself.

feat.name: Transform Armor
feat.requirements: You're wearing your armor innovation or holding it in both hands in its compact form (see text).
entries: You've modified your armor to collapse into a much smaller, compact form. In compact form, your armor innovation is easier to carry, with a Bulk 1 lower than the Bulk listed for it, to a minimum of light Bulk (carried armor normally has a Bulk 1 higher than listed in the armor entry)

You can Transform your Armor into or out of its compact form to put it on or take it off in an instant. If you're wearing your armor innovation when you Transform it, you remove it instantly, and it collapses into its compact form, which is held in both of your hands (if you don't have both hands available, it falls to the ground in an adjacent space). If you're holding your armor in compact form when you Transform it, it unfolds back into its armor form onto your body.

feat.name: Transform Construct
entries: You've modified your construct companion and built it out of light materials, allowing you to collapse it into a carrying case or another compact and innocuous form. In compact form, your construct is easily carried with a Bulk of 2 if it's Small, 4 if it's Medium, or 8 if it's Large. The compact form has wheels, allowing you to easily drag it behind you at half Speed (rather than the usual slower Speed for dragging)
Either your construct or you (if adjacent to it) can Transform your Construct.

feat.name: Advanced Construct Companion
entries: You've upgraded your construct companion's power and decision-making ability. Your construct companion becomes an advanced construct companion (page 27). During an encounter, even if you don't use the {@trait Minion|CRB|Command a Minion} action, your construct companion can still use 1 action on your turn that round to {@action Stride|CRB} or {@action Strike|CRB}.

feat.name: Diving Armor
entries: You've modified your armor with features like fins, rotors, and other gadgets to make it easy for you to move through the water, plus mechanical gills that can help you extract breathable air from water. While wearing your armor innovation, you can breathe underwater and gain a swim Speed equal to your land Speed.

feat.name: Dual-form Weapon
entries: You've built your innovation with replaceable interlocking pieces, allowing you to transform it into another type of weapon entirely. When you select this feat, choose a level-0 simple or martial weapon: a common weapon or another to which you have access. This weapon becomes your innovation's second configuration.
Select a new set of weapon modifications for this new configuration. You can spend two {@action Interact|CRB} actions to switch your weapon innovation between the two configurations.

These actions don't need to be taken consecutively, but if you've provided the first and not the second the weapon is non-functional. Your weapon's Bulk is always the greater Bulk of the two configurations, regardless of which configuration it's in—if one weapon is smaller than the other, you still need to keep any weapon parts on hand.

feat.name: Megaton Strike
entries: You activate gears, explosives, and other {@condition hidden} gadgets in your innovation to make a powerful attack. If you're wearing your innovation, make a melee unarmed {@action Strike|CRB} or a melee {@action Strike|CRB} with one weapon you chose during daily preparations; if you have a minion innovation, it makes a {@action Strike|CRB}; and if you have a weapon innovation, make a {@action Strike|CRB} with your innovation.

If the {@action Strike|CRB} hits, it deals double the usual number of weapon damage dice (two for a weapon without a striking rune, four for a striking weapon, six for a greater striking weapon, and eight for a major striking weapon).
feat.special: If your innovation is a minion, it can take this action rather than you.

feat.name: Clockwork Celerity
feat.trigger: Your turn begins.
entries: Unstable clockwork devices in your innovation allow you to push your innovation to act more quickly. You're {@condition quickened} for this turn. How you can use the extra action depends on your innovation.

items: {@bold Armor} You can use the extra action to {@action Step|CRB}, {@action Stride|CRB}, or use another movement action granted by your innovation (such as {@action Swim|CRB} if you have the Diving Armor feat).
{@bold Construct} You can use the extra action to Command your minion.
{@bold Weapon} You can use the extra action to {@action Strike|CRB} with your innovation

feat.name: Megavolt
entries: You cause your innovation to shoot out a bolt of electricity, damaging creatures in a line. Creatures in a 60-foot line from you take {@dice 3d12} electricity damage with a basic Reflex save against your class DC.

The electricity damage increases by {@dice 1d12} at 8th level and every 2 levels thereafter. You can choose to increase the line to 90 feet long if you have the breakthrough innovation class feature and to 90 or 120 feet long if you have the revolutionary innovation class feature.
feat.special: If your innovation is a minion, it can use this action rather than you.

feat.name: Visual Fidelity
entries: You've found a way to use a hodgepodge combination of devices to enhance your visual abilities in every situation.

You gain {@ability darkvision} and low-light vision, and you can see {@condition invisible} creatures and objects as translucent shapes, though these shapes appear indistinct enough to be {@condition concealed} to you. If an effect would give you the {@condition blinded} condition, the effect must attempt a counteract check against you. On a failed counteract check, you aren't {@condition blinded}, as your various devices are able to compensate.

feat.name: Gigaton Strike
entries: When you make a Megaton {@action Strike|CRB}, you can knock your foe back, sending them reeling away from the explosive force of your blow. On a successful Megaton {@action Strike|CRB}, your target must attempt a Fortitude save against your class DC.

entries.Success: The target is pushed back 5 feet.
entries.Failure: The target is pushed back 10 feet.
entries.Critical Failure: The target is pushed back 20 feet.

feat.special: If your innovation is a minion, this benefit applies on its Megaton {@action Strike|CRB|Strikes}.

feat.name: Incredible Construct Companion
entries: Thanks to your continual tinkering, your construct companion has advanced to an incredible, new stage of engineering. Your construct companion becomes an incredible construct companion (page 27).

feat.name: Overdrive Ally
feat.requirements: You're currently under the effects of {@action Overdrive|PT:G&G}.
entries: You quickly fling some of your powered-up gadgets to an ally, sharing your benefits briefly with them. Choose an ally within 30 feet. Until the end of their next turn, that ally gains the same amount of additional damage to their {@action Strike|CRB|Strikes} as you currently gain from {@action Overdrive|PT:G&G}.

feat.name: Electrify Armor
feat.requirements: You're wearing your armor innovation.
entries: You create an unstable chain reaction, causing countless sparks to dance across your armor. For 1 minute, any creature that touches you or that hits you with a melee unarmed attack or non-reach melee weapon attack takes {@dice 1d12} electricity damage.
If you have the revolutionary innovation class feature, the damage increases to {@dice 2d12}.

feat.name: Manifold Modifications
entries: You've modified your innovation using several clever workarounds and unique adjustments, allowing you to include another initial modification. Your innovation gains an additional initial modification from the list of innovations for its type.

feat.name: Tinker's Meddling
entries: You don't just tinker with your own innovation, you meddle with your allies' weapons as well. Choose an ally in your reach and one of their weapons. Attempt a {@skill Crafting} check against a high DC for your level.

entries.Success: For 1 minute, the chosen ally's {@action Strike|CRB|Strikes} with the chosen weapon gains the same offensive boost your innovation has.
entries.Critical Failure: Your ally takes damage of the type and amount that your offensive boost normally deals on a successful {@action Strike|CRB}.

feat.name: Boost Modulation
entries: You aren't satisfied with keeping to just one kind of boost from your constant tinkering. Choose two additional offensive boosts (page 17). You can use an {@action Interact|CRB} action to change the offensive boost currently affecting your weapon, choosing between the one you chose for the class feature and the two you chose for this modification. If your weapon has the modular trait, when you use an {@action Interact|CRB} action to change the physical damage type, you can swap the offensive boost as well.

feat.name: Gigavolt
entries: When you unleash electricity from your innovation, you can cause it to bounce off obstacles, creating a field of electric death. When you use Megavolt, if your line of electricity hits a solid barrier, such as a wall, it bounces off at an angle of your choice and continues until you have reached the full length of the line.
